. Hi @sc-03,
you need to extend the layoutBuilder.js - best to extend the processLeaf method to handle dd like this:
javascript
var dd = {content: [{text: 'Google', link: 'http://google.com/'}]};
To actually write the link to the pdf, you need to also extend the renderLine in printer.js. Unfortunately we are not using pdfkit for writing the text - but you should be able to use the mentioned link function.
Let me know if you need more.
. We would be happy to accept a pull request ;-)
. The filesaver is (surprise) for saving/downloading files - this will need
user interaction anyway and therefore cannot be done in a web worker.
So my approach would be to split the generation of the PDF and the handling
of its output - download, open and so on. Then the 'slow' generation is
done, while the interaction stays in the browser.
Make sure to create integration tests which indicate when someone
accidentally breaks web worker compatibility again.
Best regards
Johannes

. Hi @wwwmir3cq,
Thanks for the suggestion. We can upgrade the pdfkit library but the issue will not go away. 
Why? There are two ways to use fonts in pdfs. 
- Using a standard font - which is supported directly by your PDF viewer. 
- Using a custom font embedded into the PDF.
The fix you present uses a standard font. But pdfmake only uses embedded fonts.
Using embedded fonts is easier for a library like pdfmake, because we can use it to calculate the width of a text. 
However, I'm happy to accept a pull request when someone wants to offer using a standard font.

The Problem is not only about the missing Blob.js, but mainly, because IE9 doesn't support data: URLs to be opened in new windows or iframes. There is just no way in IE9 to save a File which comes from the client side. At least non that I know of. This is also the reason why FileSaver.js doesn't come with Blob.js included. Only IE9 is missing the Blob implementation but it isn't capable of saving files anyway...

honi:
Regarding the "No unicode cmap for font", it looks like it is a pdfkit issue. 
See: https://github.com/devongovett/pdfkit/issues/121
And it looks like some progress was made in order to fix this for some fonts: https://github.com/devongovett/pdfkit/pull/276
But since pdfmake uses a fork of pdfkit, that commit is not yet merged.
@bpampuch is there any chance you could update your pdfkit fork?

If you are creating the full doc definition outside the web worker, why do you need pdfmake at all inside the worker? Why not just message over a url blob of the complete pdf?. Just get the datauri of your barcode and add it as an image. -images example-
``` javascript
var canv = document.createElement('canvas')
drawBarcodeOnCanvasUsingSomeLibrary(canv)
var imgdata = canv.toDataURL('image/png')
docDefinition.content.push({ img: imgdata })
```
For best image quality, make your canvas about 4 times the size you really need and downscale when defining the document.
There is also a "canvas" property in pdfmake that exposes pdfkit vector drawing. -vectors example- If your library generates SVG, you could probably convert it to match the API.

Solution:
Make another string converter with support functions implemented in
pdfmake.
During creation Worker in script, I suppose is not good include full
pdfmake script? So we need to do another script file with class -
pdfMakePreparer (Any better ideas?), which will only allow safely convert
docDefinition to string or/and call postMessage on Worker with
stringDocDefinition.
And in worker skript will be used standard pdfmake method pdfMake.createPdf(
dd ), where createPdf if they receive docDefiniton as string through
safety convert string to docDefinition.
Examples:
var docDefinition = {
 // ... standard docDefinition
}
myWorker = new Worker('worker.js');
pdfMakePreparer.postMessage(myWorker, docDefinition); // internaly this make convert docDefinition to string with own JSON.stringify and call myWorker.postMessage(stringDocDefinition);
// or
var stringDocDefinition = pdfMakePreparer.prepareDocDefinition(docDefinition); // only internaly convert
myWorker.postMessage(stringDocDefinition );
worker.js:
onmessage = function(e) {
// If is e.data as string make transform with own JSON.parse from string to docDefinition inside createPdf
  var doc = pdfMake.createPdf(e.data)
  doc.getBlob();
  // etc.
};

FinnStutzenstein:
Hi
Yes, we at OpenSlides use exactly these three hacks to use PdfMake within web workers.
Problem 1:
Should be easy to fix.
Problem 2:
To use WebWorkers you have to have (at least) two scripts. In the WebWorker script just the casting from docDefinition --> blob/b64/.. is done. So the worker script has not to include FileSaver.
Also for a production use this is helpful, because you may handle these two js files different. The worker script should not be squashed together in the main js sourcemap, but rather stay alone.
Problem 3:


Use eval. Our team thought about that, because the functions passe dare very small and simple. But there are two main reasons against eval:

Larger functions are not nice to handle as strings
May not in this scenario - where the string is constant - but when having user input (may for formatting the footer string) eval is a huge security issue.



Templates: Our current solution, as we cannot pass functions. Not very nice, but just for the two places, it's ok. -> Not ok for a upstream solution.


Do some prerendering. Convert the docDefinition in something serialize able, what has to be fully rendered in the worker. This should not take a long time. Unfortunately, I've not looked very deep in the PdfMake source, that I can evaluate, if this is a good option. But, as a fact, we have to get a string, so some pre evaluating has to be done here.


If this is implemented, PdfMake should hide the WebWorkers by just giving the option, to generate the pdf async. A setting to specify the worker filename would be great. And two separate files are necessary and the worder script should not contain the whole PdfMake source.. > If you are creating the full doc definition outside the web worker, why do you need pdfmake at all inside the worker? Why not just message over a url blob of the complete pdf?
Did I get you right that you want to create the pdf blob outside of the worker and just pass the url to the worker? If so, you get this wrong: The creation of the doc definition is fast; we want to source out the converting json->pdf (doc definition -> blob/b64) in fact that this can took several minutes. For this conversion we need like 98% of pdfmake (except the download thing) inside of the web worker. The creation of the doc definition has nothing to do with pdfmake. This is just placing javascript arrays and objects with data in the right format that pdfmake can parse this.. +1
. Thanks for the fast reply!
Yes, we define the image directly with the base64 data. I've implemented custom fonts for the pdf (https://github.com/OpenSlides/OpenSlides/pull/3568; especially note the changes in core/pdf-worker.js and core/pdf.js if you are interested) where we are overwriting PdfMake.vfs on the client with our custom font data. When this font-feature is merged (currently under review) I'll try your first example by adding the image data not the the docDefinition but to the vfs object.
The different possibilities to include images should be documented in the readme ;). Hm, I played a bit around. There are three parts, that takes time during the PDF generation: the createPdfKitDocument with builder.layoutDocument and renderPages and the actual callbacks until PdfKit writes the document. The interesting thing is, that the builder - where the qr codes are generated - took only about 1,5 sec with 500 qr codes. Caching didn't improved this a lot. The actual bottleneck here is the renderer with about 13 sec and writing the document (about 20 sec).
The qr codes consists of much little rectangles that have to be rendered. Do you know if PdfKit has a feature to group rendered elements and cache those? In fact, we should render the qr code once, an in the best case use the rendered information to just put the code to other places.
Another idea: Do you think it's faster to create an image of the qrcode and just put the image every where the qr code is? What I mean is generating base64 image data, put it in the vfs and replace the qr element with an image element.

. We used the following approach to fix the problem
See comment from 'tonitornado' - https://github.com/devongovett/pdfkit/issues/69.
- Get ttf font files => normal, bold, italic and italic bold; (we used times new roman)
- Convert the ttf to otf => http://everythingfonts.com/ttf-to-otf;
- Convert otf to ttf => http://everythingfonts.com/ttf-to-otf;
- Build fonts on pdfmake => https://github.com/bpampuch/pdfmake/issues/33;
- Replace vfs_fonts.js

I think you'll find the data URL produced for the PDF is too large for the browser. The latest version of Chrome only supports 2MB and FireFox is presumably lower (1MB).. Wow, I'm glad I found this issue.
I'm generating pretty detailed forms and potentially there is a need for hundreds of them to be generated.
Using the Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER fix above a 98 page test went from 9 minutes to around 10 seconds. Absolutely stunning.
As we only have chrome where it will be used, I'm very satisfied with this. Definitely going to help out the development where I can.
Thank you.
. In Chrome it has a max dataURL string of 2MB, anything longer and it'll just open a blank tab.
. For the speed issue, see here:
https://github.com/bpampuch/pdfmake/issues/280#issuecomment-148335977
Generating my 100 page document went from 9 mins to about 10 seconds in chrome.. I found that if the top or bottom page margins are not big enough to contain the header or footer, they do not show.
Might not be your issue but worth a try to temporarily increase them.
. I had this issue also.
I believe it is the browsers fault (blocking the image). JavaScript in Chrome especially, seems to require user interaction to use any local files (file input, or drag n drop).
I had to create the data url's and save them in an array, then I used those strings in the image dictionary.. Might be a hassle getting them in first, but they shouldn't be a problem. I mean, with pdfmake and jquery,... there is already like 2~ Mb of code. And using a small python script or something you could run through a directory of files pretty easily and generate the script.
Or all the flags could be combined to a single image. Then JS could select a pixel region from it to use.. As pdfmake is designed to generate a PDF based on a layout or document definition, you will need to create the document how you would like it. It is not an image manipulation tool.

You can create your image in a canvas object
Split the canvas into logical sections (page sized chunks)
Create a data URI for each section
Add each data URI as an image to a document with a page break after each.
Generate PDF
Profit. I have had issues with the image dimensions.

To be sure the image data is actually correct, do a test with a fit command to shrink it to dimensions that fit inside the document.
If the image shows up, then your image is too large for the page. I have had this issue and the images simply do not show when too big.
Oops, just read more of your post, and yes it definitely is the issue if you wish it to flow onto a second page.
Before creating the document definition, use JS/canvas element and cut the picture up, then create data URLs for the pieces.. @liborm85 Thank you, I've been looking for a way to do that easily.. I'm happy with gulp. It is what I use in my projects. Have never used grunt.
Its still in the history, so if it turns out we need it, its simple to dig out of the trash.. It might also be worth collecting the data URI lengths for the browsers. Because after this length only the download() option works (instead of open(), I haven't tried print()).
I know, in windows (7, 64-bit), the latest version of chrome supports 2MB and FireFox supports 1MB data URI's..

. Quite strangely I found a workaround.
In previous version I used to import pdfmake and the font file in the vendor file and then import pdfmake where I use it without having to reimport the fonts.
With webpack 4 I have to import font every time I import pdfmake to fix this issue.
I'll mark this as closed but the behavior is still quite strange.. In the end the issue was a bad configuration of the webpack config file (in my case at least).
With webpack 4 previous chunk plugin is integrated and requires a new configuration to work correctly. If not correctly done each chunk file contains all the code and imports are not shared any more which explain why my pdfmake configuration done in my vendor.js file is not working in my main.js file.
I don't know if you have the same issue but I hope that could help.. You're right. Adblock seems to stop it.

devongovett:
Hey guys, I maintain PDFKit, the library that pdfmake uses to actually write PDFs. I've been working on a new font engine called fontkit which will power PDFKit's font support going forward. It supports tons of advanced typographical features, including ligatures, kerning, contextual substitutions, TrueType and PostScript outlines, etc. in both OpenType and AAT fonts. There's a branch of PDFKit using fontkit currently in progress. It embeds fonts as PDF CID fonts, which allows for much better support for large character sets.
I hope to release it very soon (working on a few final issues), but if you're feeling adventurous, please try out the fontkit branch of PDFKit and see if it works with pdfmake. It is likely that some modifications will be needed here if pdfmake accesses font properties directly, so I thought I'd let you all know so you know where we're heading. Let me know if you have any issues!
. FYI, pdfkit v0.8.0 now uses fontkit, and embeds fonts as CID fonts into the PDF, so large character sets can be supported better. With the way pdfmake uses some of the PDFKit internals, I imagine that it will be a decent amount of work to upgrade, but it should be worth it if someone has the time.
For a list of other features introduced by fontkit see the PR: https://github.com/devongovett/pdfkit/pull/534.
. That flips the PDF coordinate system, which has the origin in the bottom left corner of the page instead of the top left. Without that line, text that is supposed to be at the top of the page will render upside down at the bottom of the page.
. Khmer and other complex scripts require additional processing prior to rendering that PDFKit and pdfmake do not currently do. This includes unicode syllable analysis and reordering, and correct OpenType shaping. See the Khmer OpenType spec from Microsoft for more details.
I'm working on a new font engine for PDFKit that aims to eventually support complex script shaping. It is a big job, however, so it will take some time. Currently, fontkit supports OpenType shaping, but does not automatically select the right features for you based on the script analysis.
. This is coming very soon to pdfkit, via fontkit.
. pdfmake should use https://github.com/devongovett/linebreak for linebreaking, as PDFKit does. It implements the unicode line breaking algorithm, and supports chinese and many other languages correctly.
. fontkit 1.7 has full support for indic scripts, including Kannada and 9 others. See https://github.com/devongovett/fontkit/pull/99 for details.. Upgrading to use fontkit in pdfmake will be a larger task than just updating to PDFKit v0.8.0. Looks like pdfmake doesn't use PDFKit's text method, opting to write to the PDF manually, and it uses a bunch of PDFKit internals that have changed. To take advantage of the new features, the easiest way forward is to use PDFKit's text method, with line wrapping turned off so you can control that yourselves.
As for the issue with opening fonts, it is caused by pdfmake's generated font name. Fontkit looks for a sub-font (in this case, a variation) with that postscript name, which doesn't exist in the font.
. Made a PR https://github.com/bpampuch/pdfmake/pull/689
. @npdexsvs that doesn't appear to be caused by my changes. It happens in other builds on Travis. Anyway, it's caused by this line.
. Well, tests are passing on Travis, and my local machine. And I tried the dev server, and that works fine too.
. Merged a performance optimization for kerning in fontkit. https://github.com/devongovett/fontkit/pull/70 Please re-install and try again.. Just implemented a cache around fontkit in PDFKit: https://github.com/devongovett/pdfkit/commit/6e9e58f5d2c9c0c8b9aa9cfe3076f381310d80c5. This should improve performance significantly. It is released in PDFKit v0.8.2.
In order to increase cache efficiency, it splits up text by words and makes a separate fontkit call for each one, then caches the results. Please let me know if you see any bugs because of that. Particularly, any fonts with GSUB or GPOS adjustments around space characters won't be triggered anymore, though this should be rare.. @sklinga sounds like maybe the font has no name table. can you please send the file to me? devongovett@gmail.com.

   * @param  {String}   url

   * @param  {String}   [outputFormat=image/png]
  ###
  convertImgToBase64URL = (url, callback, outputFormat) ->
    Ember.debug 'convertImgToBase64URL'
    canvas = document.createElement 'CANVAS'
    ctx = canvas.getContext '2d'
    img = new Image

    img.crossOrigin = 'Anonymous'
    img.onload = ->

IE inserts bidirectional control characters around the date. This is by design so the output text will flow properly when concatenated with other text. This is especially important when mixing LTR and RTL content such as concatenating a formatted RTL date with LTR text.

In my case, it's a US date so it's safe to remove the invisible characters:
javascript
new Intl.DateTimeFormat('en-US', {year: 'numeric', month: 'long', day: '2-digit'})
.format(new Date()).replace(/\u200E/g,"")

```.
Thank you all :smile: . You just need to set a "global" variable (to control row background) in true or false depending row of your table. 
For example, you may to set "true" on even rows (2, 4, 6... table index 1, 3, 5) and "false" on odd rows (1, 3, 5... table index 0, 2, 4).
Odd rows won't be background-colored, so in some indexes the variable controlling background will be false; by other hand, even rows will be background-colored, var will be true. Depending on your logic you can achieve something like this.
If current index (while looping array to print the table) representing a row, will be background-colored, you may to do something like this:
columns: [
   {width: 'auto', text: $filter('nameFilter')(sector.name), style: 'tableContent'},
   {
      width: 'auto', text: ' ' + sector.cont, style: ['tableContent', 'red', 'boldText', 'superscript']
   }
], columnGap: 2, fillColor: rowBackground ? cellBackgroundColor : ""
cellBackgroundColor is a variable containing color in HEX format ("#EAEAEA" for example).
Look at fillColor statement: print this section if rowBackground is true / else don't set a color.
Easy, like this, hope this helps.
```

hutch120:
I realise this issue is pretty old, but I had the same timing issue and got it working, so thought I'd share this info.
I combined the two files into one using notepad and saved as pdfmake.vfs_fonts.min.js, then loaded the combined library and pdfjs libraries using jQuery.
This snippet may be useful for delay loading PDF generator and viewer.
$.when(
        $.cachedScript("/libs/pdfmake/0.1.20/pdfmake.vfs_fonts.min.js"),
        $.cachedScript("https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/pdf.js/1.5.389/pdf.combined.min.js")
        $.Deferred(function (deferred) {
          $(deferred.resolve)
        })
      )
      .done(function () {
        cb()
      })
Note: see $.getScript for cachedScript implementation here: https://api.jquery.com/jquery.getscript/

. Hi Girish,
IMHO the issue isn't really related to PDFMake, it is more a standards issue with how browsers implement their PDF viewers.
So then the answer becomes obvious, don't rely on browser implementation, instead, to ensure consistency between browsers use a PDF viewer library like pdf.js rather than rely on the built in PDF viewer.  https://mozilla.github.io/pdf.js/
Hope this helps. :)

stephenanders:
It appears this up-scaling is happening b/c the default unit for pdfmake is points.  When no size is passed for the image, it gets the dimensions from the parsed image's header information.  However, the image's dimensions in the header are in pixels "PNG - Width and height give the image dimensions in pixels.".  So, when pdfmake determines the size of the image, that value is in pixels, but it assumes the value is in points - resulting in the 4/3 scaling which we see in the pdf.
I've been trying to modify pdfmake.js to convert the pixel values to points before inserting the image onto the page, but so far, am not having any luck. 
Has anyone else encountered this and have a working fix or workaround?  I will continue working on this, but if someone else has already accomplished what I'm trying to do, I'd love to get that code!!

I'm not sure if the following will help you at all for in-browser performance, but we found that the following dramatically sped up our performance on the server using node.js to generate the PDFs by updating the code to turn on compression by default.
We were writing the PDF out to file and the compression made a huge difference.
Issue #622 
. Curious if the outstanding pull request from liborm85 will be considered to be merged into the project.  We are also looking to use the watermark feature but are receiving font exceptions when we're attempting to use it.
. For us we were able to get it working by changing the line 
font: fontProvider.provideFont(fontProvider[defaultFont], false, false),
to 
font: fontProvider.provideFont(defaultFont, false, false),
in LayoutBuilder.prototype.addWatermark
. You can use the header function to modify the contents of the header based on the current page number.
This is done by assigning a function to the header:
mydoc.header = function(currentPage, pageCount) {
   // do logic and return object that represents header for current page
  if (currentPage == 3) {
    return { foo: 'bar' }
  }
}
. Have you tried using the watermark property of the root PDF document.  We have used it in our implementation and it works quite well.  It only allows for a string value, but that is all we needed.
You could also do a translucent image and set its absolute position to float over the content by setting the image's absolultePosition property
https://github.com/bpampuch/pdfmake/blob/master/examples/absolute.js
But for a document where you want the watermark on each page I would recommend the watermark property so that you don't have to repeat a translucent image on each page.

jeffrey-cochran:
Something tells me they are not in TWIPS. Namely, a TWIP seems to be 1/1440 of an inch, and that would imply the standard page sizes given are absurdly small (see the documentation). In fact, I believe the default page size is defined as A4 in printer.js: width=595.28, height=841.89. If it were twips, this would be fractions of an inch. Knowing that the true width of the A4 standard is 8.3 inches, we would expect that to imply that 595.28/8.3=71.7 is the scaling factor (call it dpi or whatever you want). However, this is almost certainly just rounding error, and in fact, the scaling factor from inches to insert whatever these mysterious units ACTUALLY are is 72 as mentioned above. In any case, I do believe that the margins use the same units, and I believe their default value is 40 on each side.

var encoded = watermark.font.encode(watermark.text); returns a blank string, and doesnt have the extended properties the function is looking for later on.
By changing 
pdfKitDoc.addContent('/' + encoded.fontId + ' ' + watermark.size.fontSize + ' Tf'); to
pdfKitDoc.addContent('/ ' + watermark.size.fontSize + ' Tf');
and
pdfKitDoc.addContent('<' + encoded.encodedText + '> Tj'); to
pdfKitDoc.addContent('(' + watermark.text + ') Tj');
I was able to get a watermark to show up in the correct position, albeit with a generic font rather than anything I had selected.

st33bz:
I encountered the same problem and identified the behavior, if not the cause. The .open() method applies x and y coordinates to image objects in the content or column arrays built. The x value appears to increment itself each time .open() executes, however, rather than just being set once or remeasuring from 0 every time. The result seems to be that images in some circumstances move across the page by the width of the left margin every time the object updates.
I worked around this temporarily by using the .resetXY() method that I stumbled into when picking apart the object.
In your structure identified above, the syntax would be something like:
docDef.content[0].columns[0].resetXY();
fired after you call .open().
It will require someone with much more familiarity with the library than I have to correct the underlying problem, though.
.

DavidWeil:
Is pdfmake generating the PDF file in a re-entrant manner?  We have a servlet that generates PDF reports and returns a one-time context path, which responds with an inline PDF.  What we observe (from wireshark) is Edge re-issuing the request once the PDF viewer opens in a new browser tab (instead of passing the response content to the new tab).  Since the path is one-time (the backing temporary file is delete on close), Edge fails to display the PDF.  (In our case the error is easy to see, since the servlet generates a 500 error for file-not-found.)

juliekirwin:
@Dejab666  I ended up setting dontbreakrows: true and made my image size a static width and divided the remaining page width between the rest of the columns. This seemed to fix the issue for me. 
Javascript
table: { 
     headerRows: 1,
     dontBreakRows:true, 
     widths: $scope.colWidths,
     body: $scope.body 
}
For the page widths I had to get a little creative. Here is the array I used to select paper size.... I have to admit it was a little brute force / hacky, but I needed to get it done. 
``` Javascript
$scope.formats = [{ID : 'Executive', width: 522, height: 756}, {ID : 'Folio', width: 612, height:  936},
    { ID: 'Legal', width: 612, height: 1008 }, { ID: 'Letter', width: 612, height: 792 },
```

When my code tries to build two documents, one after another, pdfMake.createPdf(docDefinition).open(), effectively opens and focus in the new window before is has built the second one. When the second document is built and pdfMake.createPdf(docDefinition).open() executes again, it happens in the new opened window; I mean, not in the original window, and the error occurs because of that.

ljfolino:
Not sure if this will work for you but I had a similar issue.  Some of the observations I had when creating a dynamic data table was that I had to have exactly the same number of elements per row.  This meant converting nulls/undefined to empty strings.  I created a helper function to do that.
The second issue I found was that I couldn't include the column headers with the array in the doc definition.  What I ended up doing was adding the headers to the array instead of including both in the doc definition.
Like this
outside doc def
var items = getFromRemote();
items.unshift(header);
in doc definition
                  table:
                            {
                                headerRows: 1,
                                widths: ['7%', '7%', '', '7%', 'auto', '5%', '7%', '7%', '7%', 'auto', ''],
                                body: items
},

@likebrain,
There are some pros and cons about "separating" into new repo.
Pros: we can choose maintainer and contributors to the repo and we can accept pull requests as well.
Cons: there is already an official site, pdfmake.org. As this repo is abondoned, people will be somehow confused of this repo and our fork, where to find it and so on. And we cannot update the site as well.
That's why I chose to rename my fork to pdfmake2 and we should definitely think of it too.
Beside that, I saw contributors of this repo besides it's owner @bpampuch. Seems to me they are not active too but it would be great to hear something from them in this thread.

pemaxim:
It works great, thanks @liborm85 ! But, is it possible to set _target=blank for link somehow?
. @uanthwal Sorry, but I did not understand your question. Which feature are you asking about? If you're asking how to open links in new window, - there is no solution. Also, here is what I found:

PDFs are not marked up with HTML. How a link click is handled in a PDF depends on the PDF viewer you are using. Modern browsers with built-in PDF viewers may navigate to the page within the same frame as the PDF view and that is not something that can be controlled with an HTML element attribute. What happens if your link is clicked when the PDF is being viewed in Adobe Acrobat or Mac Preview? You're at the whim of the software and operating system. Sorry to bear the bad news but this is the reality of the PDF format.

Related topic: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/36637266/can-not-generate-blank-links-on-pdf-via-pdfkit-on-rails-app 
. +1
.

akomelj:
Current auto page height calculation works only for simple PDFs.
The problem lies in the page.items.forEachloop which adds item height of every page item to the total page height. This logic does not work when items are rendered in parallel (e.g. two columns in a single line, etc.) as height of both items is being added instead of height of the higher item only.
I am not familiar with page rendering mechanism but one of the possible options for calculating page height would be to take y coordinate of the LAST page item and add item height to that (+ margin of course). This obviously only works if the page items are being added from top to bottom..

saravp2016:
Sorry for late response, I was away during weekend.
@liborm85 Thanks for referring to the existing issue, I believe here also it should be HTML encoding related issue.
But I got below HTML tags already in my HTML. Still I face this issue in my production environment.

In my local Dev enviornment I use Spring boot's embedded tomcat server, while in my Prod I use Jboss server. Since the HTML code is same and also it has necessary tags with it, I doubt it could be something to do with server.
So looking into my Jboss server to have any configuration to force UTF-8 encoding for the HTML served. Not sure this is right approach, I appreciate if somebody can validate this approach or provide a solution in this regard.. The issue was fixed. Root cause was outdated HTML encoding.
Jhipster have implemented EmbeddedServletContainerCustomizer in their WebConfiguer.java to add charset(UTF-8) information for their HTML pages served through embedded tomcat server.
But external server(in my case jboss) by default was considering some outdated encoding unless we force it to serve UTF-8 encoded HTML pages. Since it was a spring boot application, I set the charset details in their application.yml/properties file as below and it worked:

Thanks @liborm85  once again for guiding through right path. Since prod WAR was minified, uglified, etc I was considering those process would have broken the JS somewhere and spend more time on it. I would have never thought of HTML encoding as cause of the issue.
Am closing the issue as it was fixed.

vidaljessi:
This work for me:
createPDF = (docDefinition, DOCUMENT_NAME) ->
  future = new Future
  printer = new PdfPrinter(fonts)
  finalString = ''
  try
    doc = printer.createPdfKitDocument(docDefinition)
    doc.end()
    stream = doc.pipe(base64.encode())
    stream.on 'data', (chunk) ->
      finalString += chunk
      return
    stream.on 'end', Meteor.bindEnvironment(->
      future.return finalString
      return
    )
  catch error
    loggr.error {error: error}, 'create-pdf-error'
    return
  return future.wait().

cah-alexsukhodolsky:
The issue was less with pdfmake and more with webpack. But I've got it working!
Specifically, I needed to:

npm install --save-dev copy-webpack-plugin
import and use the CopyWebpackPlugin and add it to the plugins section with the following config:
new CopyWebpackPlugin([{from: 'node_modules/pdfmake/build/pdfmake.min.js'},{from: 'node_modules/pdfmake/build/vfs_fonts.js'}])
Add references to the js files in index.html:
<script src='/pdfmake.min.js'></script>
<script src='/vfs_fonts.js'></script>
NOT import pdfMake into my React/Angular component. Simply use the global instance. . @XeniaSiskaki I found that importing the libraries in a React component with a require/import statement didn't properly run the vfs_fonts.js code. Specifically, all vfs_fonts.js does is add a vfs property to the window.pdfmake object (it creates a window.pdfmake object if one doesn't exist already).
It's possibly that using require doesn't properly run the vfs_fonts.js code. Or maybe it runs it out of order and the pdfmake.js ends up overriding the window.pdfmake object.
Either way, setting up webpack to copy the pdfmake/vfs_fonts files to the build directory and importing them directly in index.html got pdfmake working correctly (even with 0.1.28)..

gilphilbert:
I noticed something similar when using OTF files and couldn't work out why TTFs worked fine. It turns out that the PDF reader I was using (the one built into Chrome) seems to handle TTFs but not OTFs - I was seeing exactly what you're seeing. The OTF versions worked fine in Acrobat.
I've moved to TTFs to support a wider range of PDF readers. You can convert OTF files to TTF online for free if needed (just make sure the font's license allows it)..
atiertant:
@alexisab you can try
npm install Atlantis-software/pdfmake#atlantis
it's a modified version of pdfmake with performance optimizations (image size, qrcode, progress callback, ...) that use a modified version of pdfkit reducing memory usage.
but we got an other bug you should have too : createPdfKitDocument function break javascript event loop as it is a long processing synchronous function, while generating PDF, javascript can't do anything else and asynchronous function called in progress callback are done after createPdfKitDocument end.. @soohan92 try using it in your package.json. @Jbegley1995 there are many problems:
- all pdfkit and pdfmake methods are synchronous (should return promise to avoid breaking changes)
- pdfkit streams does not respect backpressure
- node zlib has memory leaks (https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/8871) we used synchronous deflate to avoid this problem but this is slower. docDefinition.images was used to store base64 images but as we convert them to buffer, we don't need it anymore. @liborm85 thanks for review, i made some changes to fix this. thanks for review, i fixed it. @szaim there are memory leaks in pdfkit (a lib used by pdfmake), we are waitting for a new release that fix it. 
and there is another problem in both pdfkit and pdkmake to generate big documents: they aren't asynchronous... it lock the event loop and there's no back pressure possible..

ocastx:
I have the same problem. Checked the code and found the root cause where NaN is generated: 
In the src/docMeasure.js the function measureImage function tries to calculate the size of the image by the given sizes of the image. But both the node.width and imageSize.width is defined as "20%". The code doesn't check for any width strings and tries to calculate the width size value in the following lines which generates the NaN and throws an error in the PDFKit library
node._width = node._minWidth = node._maxWidth = node.width || imageSize.width
node._height = node.height || (imageSize.height * node._width / imageSize.width);
As there is no available width given in the function it is actually not possible to calculate the correct percentage of the available width. It has to be preprocessed.
I didn't have time to find the right part of the code where preprocessing of the width values happen except for the lines in columnCalculator.js where the percentage values are converted to numbers in line 27. . Seems to be duplicate of #1085.

rmilejcz:
Just wanna add for anyone who ends up here through google, I did solve this.
Instead of using the .getBuffer() method, I used the .getBase64() method and then converted that to a bytearray and then passed that to the File constructor (if you're using node you can use the function b64toBlob, blobs work just as well I have tested and confirmed. If you're not using node, or prefer to use the File constructor, modify the code found here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16245767/creating-a-blob-from-a-base64-string-in-javascript)
From there, it's just a matter of sending that Blob/File to your server or wherever you need it to go. If it doesn't get there as a pdf you can still open it as a pdf, just be sure to add the ".pdf" extension when you name the file at upload time. .

We have resolved the issue by using the font KaigenSansSC-*.ttf (https://github.com/m13253/kaigen-fonts)

On 20 November 2017 at 05:20, FelipeMicali notifications@github.com wrote:

Hey Ross!
What you are facing is probably an async problem.
Take a look at that "i" icon in the end of your console logged array. That
indicates that the array was updated after some change was made to that
array after it was first console logged. So, in your first image, your
array has some properties created by pdfmake, and when pdfmake is not
triggered, your original array is logged.
Even if you log your array before pdfmake run, it will show the updated
array anyway, before pdfmake modifies it in sequence, and your logged array
is updated too.
Pdfmake modifies your array, so it can insert and position all it's
elements in the correct page by creating references in each object.
Javascript is an object oriented language, and should be built by that way
to accomplish better results.
Why is this being a problem to you? Try to explain us what you are trying
to achieve, and maybe we can guide you better!
Bye!

thomascallahan:
Unless PDFMake can somehow use the font data from the user's system fonts (which I highly doubt, and wouldn't give you any control over the text appearance) then there is nothing that can be done to avoid this issue. I've been dealing with this exact situation for years, first in Flash, then with SiFR, Cufon, and now web fonts. CJK character sets are just fundamentally too large to use in any case where you have to include the actual character data in any data transmission. Providing reasonable advance warning to the user of the large download, and providing a download status/progress bar, is your best bet. If the user really wants the content in your PDF, then 20mb probably won't stop them unless they're on a mobile device.
G-zipping on the server would help if that's not already being done -- vfs_fonts.js should gzip pretty well. 
Otherwise the only thing I can think of is to generate the PDFs on the server instead of the browser, or maybe generate the text portions as images on the server and include them in the PDF. Believe it or not that'll be faster for the user than transmitting the actual font files unless you're making PDFs with more than 10 or 15 pages..

On 3 March 2018 at 15:37, Libor M. notifications@github.com wrote:

Yes pages are added dynamically, example:
var dd = {
    pageSize: {width: 595.28, height: 841.89},
    pageMargins: [0, 0, 0, 0],
  content: [
      {image: 'sampleImage.jpg', width: 595.28, height: 841.89},
      {image: 'sampleImage.jpg', width: 595.28, height: 841.89},
      {image: 'sampleImage.jpg', width: 595.28, height: 841.89},
  ]
}
And you can add page manually by pageBreak in last/first element.
One image can only be on one page. If you want image on multiple pages,
cut image with some other library to more images.

I have found out what the problem was. Since I am using the global object from the JSON, i.e., vm.dynamicConfig.assignments, the object is used again and again. 
We can fix this by cloning the javascript object using JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(obj))
I have made the following changes:
var assignments = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(vm.dynamicConfig.assignments));
I updated the object for iterating over my fields:
$.each(assignments.science.fields, function (index, field) {
.

.
}

noelucien:
In the playground / tables , there are no examples regarding my request.
In fact there are only layouts specified within the content code.
In the page 
the pdfMake.tableLayouts is wrote outside the content code.
So, how I can assign the custom Layout defined outside the content code to the tables inside the content code ?
Thank's
. Normally in the docDefinition you set the layout of the tables.
But I wish to define the layout of the tables in the object  pdfMake.tableLayouts  outside of the docDefinition  object .
But I don't know how assign the layout to the tables.
I've try 
table:{...},layout: name 
where name is the name set in the tableLayouts
but does not work
Please, can you tell me how I've to do ..
Thank's. I've done it !
So, first define pdfMake.tableLayouts first of the docDefinition
Then in the docDefinition assign the custom layout to a table like this :
table:{...},layout:pdfMake.tableLayouts.Mylayout
where Mylayout is the name set in the tableLayouts
pdfMake.tableLayouts = {
     Mylayout: {...}
};
var docDefinition = { ...
table:{...},layout:pdfMake.tableLayouts.Mylayout
...}
.

Dynamically control page breaks, for instance to avoid orphan children
A pageBreakBefore function can be specified, which can determine if a page break should be inserted before a node...

pageBreakBefore: function(currentNode, followingNodesOnPage, nodesOnNextPage, previousNodesOnPage) {
     return currentNode.headlineLevel === 1 && followingNodesOnPage.length === 0;
  }

this does seem related to that other ticket, @talamatur. Just to be very clear on what I've found when using pdfmake ^0.1.50

If my app does not have filemaker as a dependency, download works as expected.
If my app depends on the same version of file-saver that pdfmake was built with, download fails. Other file-saver actions in my app still work.
If I downgrade my app's file-saver dependency, download works. alexmller:
I can confirm that building pdfMake 1.5.2 (or 1.4.0) with FileSaver.js 1.3.8 make the download-function work again while building it with 2.0.0 breaks it.
There is no test setup in the FileSaver.js repository to ensure proper regression, leaving it in the dark where exactly the root cause is of this issue is.
As a workaround, I suggest to release pdfMake with 1.3.8 FileSaver.js unless there is a real need for the changes that subsequent releases introduce..

kamilkp:
Well, every object created by PdfKit constructor consists of at least 6 objects. Each of them is an instance of PDFReference. Try executing new PdfKit().store.objects in Chrome console. It will output the following:
Object {1: PDFReference, 2: PDFReference, 3: PDFReference, 4: PDFReference, 5: PDFReference, 6: PDFReference}
When you add content or metadata to the pdf document you simply append more objects to it, but those six will always be there. I'm accessing this specific object to get ahold of its constructor because that's the object i'm going to append a reference to the embedded JS later on.
.
fuunnx:
Hi ! I was wondering if there was svg support for pdfMake then I saw you pull request. Thanks for doing it !
Now that I'm here, I find the API not declarative enough comparing to the pdfMake API, and too far from the svg one.
A better alternative would be to contain those transformations on the element being transformed instead of separate instructions :
As requested in #807
js
{ type: 'rect', x: 150, y: 200, w: 150, h: 50, rotate:45, translate: {x: 10, y: 1}, scale: 1 }
However order of transforms do matters so maybe something like that would do the job:
js
{ 
  type: 'rect', 
  x: 150,
  y: 200,
  w: 150,
  h: 50,
  transform(s): [
    {translate: {x: 10, y: 1}},
    {rotate: 45},
    {scale: 1},
  ],
}
Which is close to the svg API transform="translate(10, 1) scale(-1, 1)"
And if it is needed to apply the same operations to multiple elements maybe introduce a node of type 'group' like the <g> node in svg ?
Last point, I we want a better svg support maybe introduce 2 other transforms : skew  (and skewX and skewY) and matrix. Skew is not implemented by pdfkit but there is a generic transform method that can take any matrix, and the matrices for skew are available here : https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/transform
.
